page.title: 11Landscape Longridge Fell
page.content:
The area is dominated by the western end of the Fell, here ranging between 130m and 276m above sea level and just includes the ever-expanding boundaries of the small town of Longridge, encloaching north-eastward on rough fell farm land, mostly sheep and cattle grazing, with some meadowland below in the valley of the river Loud.
The landscape is typical of the upland country of the north-west, with its dry-stone walls, disused quarries and water-catchment and has areas of coniferous woodland to the north and eastern sides. The slopes, especially to the south, have some deciduous woodland often following the course of a 'beck' or 'clough' draining to the Ribble.
